metadata.official_name: Columbia University in the City of New York

strategic_profile.executive_summary: Columbia University is a private Ivy League research university in New York City, recognized globally for its rigorous academics, including a distinctive Core Curriculum, and extensive research across numerous fields. It offers a vibrant urban campus life deeply integrated with the vast opportunities of its metropolitan setting.
strategic_profile.admissions_philosophy: Columbia University employs a holistic admissions review, considering applicants as whole persons without specific test score or GPA cutoffs. The process also utilizes a contextual admissions review, evaluating applicants within their unique high school and family circumstances.

analyst_takeaways.insight: Columbia maintains an extremely low acceptance rate (e.g., 3.66% for the class of 2025), indicating intense competition for admission.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Prospective students need to present an exceptional and well-rounded application demonstrating strong academic achievement, unique personal qualities, and a clear fit with Columbia'        s values.

analyst_takeaways.insight: Despite past controversies and a period of non-participation with US News & World Report, Columbia continues to be recognized as a top-tier institution by various reputable ranking sources, including a recent surge in Forbes'        rankings.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Applicants and stakeholders should consider a wide array of ranking sources and institutional data to get a comprehensive view of Columbia'        s standing, rather than relying solely on any single publication.

analyst_takeaways.insight: Columbia's identity is inextricably linked to its New York City location, offering unparalleled cultural, internship, and social opportunities while maintaining a distinct campus community.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Students who thrive in a bustling metropolitan environment, are independent, and can balance rigorous academics with exploring city life will likely find Columbia to be an ideal fit.

campus_dynamics.social_environment: Columbia fosters a strong sense of community despite its urban location, offering numerous clubs and organizations, an '        Activities Day'        for recruitment, and unique traditions like '        Midnight Breakfast'        before finals. While some students engage in the city'        s nightlife, a distinct on-campus social scene and a '        bar culture'        around campus are also prevalent. The Core Curriculum plays a significant role in creating shared intellectual experiences and discourse among students.
campus_dynamics.transportation_impact: Located in a dense urban environment, Columbia benefits from New York City'        s extensive public transportation system, with a subway station (116th Street–Columbia University stop on the 1 train) directly accessible to campus. The university also operates its own comprehensive network of free shuttle services, including intercampus shuttles, an on-demand evening shuttle, and specialized routes to research facilities, minimizing the need for personal vehicles among students and staff.
campus_dynamics.research_impact: As a world-leading research institution, Columbia provides extensive research opportunities for undergraduates across all disciplines, from sciences to humanities, often involving direct work with faculty. The university boasts numerous labs, research centers, and institutes, actively pursuing breakthroughs in fields like AI, medicine, and climate science. Columbia maintains strong ties with industry, collaborating with Fortune 500 companies and startups, which provides students with access to cutting-edge projects, internships, and potential career paths in technology and innovation.

longitudinal_trends.notes: University admitted its largest incoming class ever. Waitlist data not publicly disclosed.
Third largest applicant pool in Columbia'        s history. Waitlist data not publicly disclosed.
Acceptance rate reached a record low at the time. Waitlist data not publicly disclosed.

gpa.notes: Most admitted students have unweighted GPAs above 3.9, and approximately 94% of enrolling students were in the top 10% of their high school graduating class.

testing.policy_note: Columbia is test-optional. Students who opt not to submit test scores will not be at a disadvantage. 40% of first-time enrollees submitted SAT scores.

men.note: For the Class of 2025, 50% were male.

women.note: For the Class of 2025, 48% were female.

non_binary.note: For the Class of 2025, 2% identified as non-binary.

colleges.name: Columbia College
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Strong academic record and a genuine interest in a broad liberal arts education, particularly the Core Curriculum. Applicants should demonstrate diverse intellectual interests and exceptional critical thinking abilities.
colleges.housing_profile: Guaranteed for four years, with first-year students required to live on campus in dedicated halls like Carman, Furnald, John Jay, Wallach, and Wien. Upperclassmen have varied options including corridor, suite-style, apartments, townhouses, and brownstones, as well as Special Interest Communities.
colleges.student_archetype: Intellectually curious, engaged with the rigorous Core Curriculum, highly motivated to explore New York City, and often socio-politically involved.

majors.name: Economics
prerequisite_courses: STAT UN1201 Introduction to Statistics B
majors.special_requirements: All core economics courses must be completed no later than the spring semester of the student'        s junior year and must be taken at Columbia. Students must receive a grade of C- or higher in any class taken for major credit (except ECON UN1105, which can be Pass/D/Fail with a '        P'        grade).
majors.notes: One of the most popular undergraduate majors. Students declare after admission to the College. Strongly recommends taking Calculus in high school. Department does not accept transfer credits for Intermediate Microeconomics, Intermediate Macroeconomics, and Econometrics.

majors.name: Psychology
prerequisite_courses: PSYC UN1001 The Science of Psychology (or equivalent)
weeder_courses: PSYC UN1001 The Science of Psychology
majors.special_requirements: Students must complete 11 courses in Psychology or an approved cognate discipline, with at least 6 taken in the Columbia Psychology Department. A grade of B- or better is required for transfer courses to count towards the major, and statistics courses taken outside Columbia or Barnard may not count.
majors.notes: A popular major. Introductory Psychology is a prerequisite for most other PSYC courses. Students typically declare after completing introductory coursework.

majors.name: Computer Science
prerequisite_courses: COMS W1004 Introduction to Computer Science and Programming in Java
weeder_courses: COMS W1004 Introduction to Computer Science
COMS W3134 Data Structures in Java
majors.special_requirements: Up to four transfer courses accepted toward the major; Calculus, linear algebra, and probability/statistics can be transferred in addition. Each transfer course must be approved by the Columbia instructor and passed with a B grade or higher.
majors.notes: One of the most popular majors across the university. Students in Columbia College, General Studies, and Barnard can major in Computer Science. Strong emphasis on theoretical and applied aspects.

majors.name: Political Science
prerequisite_courses: Two introductory courses from subfields (American Politics, Comparative Politics, International Relations, Political Theory)
majors.special_requirements: Nine courses in political science, including two 4-point seminars (at least one in primary subfield). Beginning Fall 2025, required introductory courses must be completed at Columbia, not Barnard. Courses in the major cannot be taken Pass/Fail. A grade of Pass is only acceptable for the first course taken toward the major. Courses with a grade of D may not be applied toward the major.
majors.notes: Students choose a primary and secondary subfield. Seminars often require instructor permission.

majors.name: Biological Sciences
prerequisite_courses: BIOL UN2005 Intro Bio I: Biochem, Gen, Molec
BIOL UN2006 Intro Bio II: Cell Bio, Dev/Phys
weeder_courses: BIOL UN2005 Intro Bio I: Biochem, Gen, Molec
BIOL UN2006 Intro Bio II: Cell Bio, Dev/Phys
majors.special_requirements: At least 4 biology or biochemistry courses and at least 18 credits of the total (biology, biochemistry, math, physics, and chemistry) must be taken at Columbia. Transfer credit for Introductory Biology is rarely granted. A grade of B- or better must be earned for transfer courses to be considered.
majors.notes: The usual introductory biology sequence is taken in the sophomore year after general chemistry. Students are encouraged to start with General Chemistry in their first year.

majors.name: English
prerequisite_courses: ENGL UN2000 Approaches to Literary Study
ENGL UN2001 Approaches to Literary Study Seminar
majors.special_requirements: Fulfillment of the English major requires the completion of at least TEN courses in the Department of English and Comparative Literature, with a grade higher than D. ENGL UN2000 and ENGL UN2001 comprise a single course and should be taken as early as possible, preferably in the freshman or sophomore year.
majors.notes: To receive departmental honors, students need a GPA of 3.65 or higher in major coursework and must submit a senior essay.

majors.name: History
majors.special_requirements: Majors are required to complete 9 history courses total, including 2 seminars, with 4 courses forming a specialization and 3 fulfilling a breadth requirement (removed in time and space). All History students MUST submit a Plan of Study (POS) approved by an Undergraduate Education Committee (UNDED) advisor to graduate. A maximum of 3 transfer or study-abroad courses may be applied toward the major.
majors.notes: Students are required to specialize in a geographic or temporal field. Departmental honors require a senior thesis.

majors.name: Human Rights
prerequisite_courses: HRTS UN3001 Introduction to Human Rights
majors.special_requirements: The major requires a minimum of 31 total credits, including HRTS UN3001, HRTS UN3190 International Human Rights Law, and HRTS UN3995 Human Rights Senior Seminar. One distributional or specialization course must be a seminar. No course with a grade of D or lower is credited towards the major. A maximum of three transfer courses may be applied towards the Major.
majors.notes: The program emphasizes interdisciplinary study of human rights. Departmental honors require a 3.6 GPA in the major and overall, and a high-quality thesis.

majors.name: Architecture
majors.notes: Columbia College offers a B.A. in Architecture. (Further specific details on requirements were not readily available in the initial search results beyond the major being offered).

colleges.name: The Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science (Columbia Engineering)
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Applicants need a strong STEM background and a passion for engineering, coupled with broad interests in business, finance, or humanities due to the interdisciplinary nature. Demonstrates curiosity and a willingness to take risks.
colleges.housing_profile: Shares housing with Columbia College students; guaranteed for four years, with first-year students required to live on campus. Options include traditional corridor and suite-style halls, apartments, and brownstones.
colleges.student_archetype: Driven by intellectual discovery, passionate about STEM fields, curious, diverse, and engaged, with many participating in hackathons and tech culture. Often described as risk-takers and leaders.

majors.name: Computer Science
majors.special_requirements: Minimum of 62 points. The major is composed of the Computer Science Core (7-8 courses), Area Foundation Courses (4 courses), Computer Science Electives (4 courses), and General Technical Electives (4 courses). A maximum of one course with a grade of D may count toward the major. Up to four transfer courses accepted.
majors.notes: Students declare their major online during the first semester of their sophomore year. ENGI E1006 is a required course for all engineering students. Some 4000-level courses are considered challenging.

majors.name: Mechanical Engineering
majors.special_requirements: Undergraduates should declare their major prior to the start of their junior year. Students declaring during or after the fall semester of their junior year need departmental approval. Cumulative GPA of at least 3.4 and strong departmental recommendations for the Integrated BS/MS program. A minimum overall GPA of 3.0 is mentioned for transfer admission to the B.S. Mechanical Engineering program.
majors.notes: Emphasizes problem-solving and teamwork. Includes a rigorous grounding in math, science, and the Core Curriculum. Many outstanding students choose this major.

majors.name: Biomedical Engineering
prerequisite_courses: ENGI E1006 Intro to Comp for Eng/App Sci
APMA E2101 Intro to Applied Mathematics
majors.special_requirements: The curriculum provides broad knowledge of physical and engineering sciences applied to biological and medical problems. Requires two semesters of Biomedical Engineering, two semesters of BME Laboratory, two semesters of Quantitative Physiology, Biostatistics for Engineering, and two semesters of BME Design.
majors.notes: Prepares graduates for careers in medical device industry, engineering consulting, biomechanics, biomedical imaging, biotechnology, or graduate/medical school.

majors.name: Chemical Engineering
prerequisite_courses: ENGI E1006 Intro to Comp for Eng/App Sci
weeder_courses: CHEE E3010 Principles of Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics I
CHEN E3230 Reaction Kinetics and Reactor Design
majors.special_requirements: Requires core courses emphasizing engineering science and practical/professional aspects. Students considering this major should take CHEN E1000 Chemical Engineering for Humanity and ENGI E1006 in their first year.
majors.notes: Accredited by ABET. Offers concentrations through technical elective choices.

majors.name: Electrical Engineering
majors.special_requirements: Students generally complete many technical requirements in their first two years. Tech electives must be 3000-level or higher.
majors.notes: Program requires fulfilling all degree requirements as outlined in the bulletin.

majors.name: Data Science
majors.notes: A relatively newer and increasingly popular major. (Specific weeder courses not explicitly found, but typically involves rigorous math and programming).

colleges.name: School of General Studies
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Designed for non-traditional students, typically over 21 or those who have had a break in their education. Ideal for mature, independent, and self-motivated individuals seeking a rigorous Ivy League undergraduate education, often balancing academics with other responsibilities.
colleges.housing_profile: Housing is managed by Columbia Residential for select undergraduates, often including options for individual or shared apartments. Some students may choose to live in fraternity/sorority housing.
colleges.student_archetype: Non-traditional, mature, independent, and highly motivated, often with diverse life experiences (e.g., veterans). Students are encouraged to be involved and can shape their unique Columbia experience.

majors.name: Computer Science
prerequisite_courses: COMS W1004 Introduction to Computer Science and Programming in Java
weeder_courses: COMS W1004 Introduction to Computer Science
COMS W3134 Data Structures in Java
majors.special_requirements: GS students pursue the same majors and take the same classes with the same professors as Columbia College undergraduates. Major requirements align with Columbia College BA in CS. Transfer credits for the major are not automatically granted and require DUS approval; at least 18 points toward the major must be taken at Columbia.
majors.notes: GS is for non-traditional students. An internal transfer process exists to SEAS, but students are limited to a total of 8 semesters including previous transfer work.

majors.name: Economics
prerequisite_courses: STAT UN1201 Introduction to Statistics B
majors.special_requirements: GS students pursue the same majors as Columbia College students; therefore, major requirements are the same. A minimum of 5 lecture courses must be taken in the Columbia Economics Department. The department does not accept transfer courses for the intermediate core economics courses.
majors.notes: Same major requirements and policies as Columbia College Economics major.

majors.name: Psychology
prerequisite_courses: PSYC UN1001 The Science of Psychology (or equivalent)
weeder_courses: PSYC UN1001 The Science of Psychology
majors.special_requirements: GS students pursue the same majors as Columbia College students. At least 6 of the 11 courses must be in the Columbia Psychology Department. Statistics courses taken anywhere other than Columbia or Barnard may not count toward the major.
majors.notes: Same major requirements and policies as Columbia College Psychology major.

majors.name: Applied Mathematics
majors.notes: Offered within the School of General Studies, aligning with Columbia College'        s offerings.

colleges.name: Barnard College
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: For independently minded and adventurous women seeking a liberal arts education within a close-knit community in a vibrant urban setting. Values students who are smart, driven, and supportive, and who will engage with both Barnard'        s resources and those of Columbia University.
colleges.housing_profile: Offers on-campus housing, with most freshmen choosing to live in dorms. The campus is small, fostering a strong sense of community, and dorms often have communal lounges. Examples include Cathedral Gardens (newest) and Brooks Hall (oldest).
colleges.student_archetype: Independently minded, adventurous, smart, and driven women who support each other. Engaged with social activism and keen to leverage the opportunities of both a small liberal arts college and New York City.

majors.name: Computer Science
prerequisite_courses: COMS W1004 Introduction to Computer Science and Programming in Java
weeder_courses: COMS W1004 Introduction to Computer Science
COMS W3134 Data Structures in Java
majors.special_requirements: Barnard CS majors follow a '        trackless'        curriculum as of Fall 2023, consisting of 14-15 courses (minimum 44 points), including a core of 6 courses, 3 Area Foundation courses, and 3 CS electives. Students entering before Fall 2023 follow an older, track-based curriculum. Major declaration is via Slate.
majors.notes: Barnard partners with Columbia'        s Computer Science department. Students have access to a broad range of upper-level courses at both institutions.

majors.name: Psychology
prerequisite_courses: PSYC BC1020 Behavioral Research Methods and Analysis
weeder_courses: PSYC BC1020 Behavioral Research Methods and Analysis
majors.special_requirements: Requires 8 PSYC/NSBV courses, 3 labs (2 PSYC, 1 outside science), and 1 cognate course. At least 6 of the 8 PSYC courses must be taken at Barnard or Columbia (non-summer). A letter grade of C- or better must be earned in all PSYC courses applied to the major.
majors.notes: Introductory courses (BC1001, BC1020, BC1101) are prerequisites for almost all other PSYC courses. Students typically declare after completing introductory coursework.

majors.name: Economics
prerequisite_courses: ECON BC1007 Math Methods for Economics (or MATH UN1101 Calculus I and MATH UN1201 Calculus III)
majors.special_requirements: The Economics track requires a minimum of 12 courses (36 minimum credits). Economics majors cannot take any economics courses P/D/F. A minimum of 3 points AP credit in Economics is allowed with a score of 4 or 5 in Macro or Micro.
majors.notes: Students pursuing this major receive rigorous training in economics and mathematics.

majors.name: Biological Sciences
prerequisite_courses: BIOL BC1502 Intro Cell and Molecular Biol
majors.special_requirements: Every biology major must complete the introductory biology and genetics courses. Students must complete five upper-level lecture courses based on their chosen track (General Biology, Cell & Molecular Biology, etc.). At least 3 semesters of lab classes and a senior capstone experience (thesis) are required. AP and IB credit do not exempt a student from any introductory course.
majors.notes: The introductory sequence is described as challenging but doable. Students are encouraged to attend office hours and start studying early.

supplemental_requirements.details: One list question (100 words or fewer) and five supplemental essays (150 words or fewer each) are required, covering topics such as intellectual development, lived experience/community contribution, navigating adversity, '        Why Us'        , and academic interests.

holistic_factors.specific_differentiators: Looking for academic potential, intellectual strength, ability to think independently, intellectual curiosity, meaningful impact, and a clear sense of purpose.

essay_prompts.prompt: Why are you interested in attending Columbia University?
brainstorming_questions: Beyond the prestige, what specific Columbia academic program, research opportunity, or faculty member has genuinely captured your intellectual curiosity and how does it align with a passion you've nurtured?
How has the unique environment of New York City, and Columbia's place within it, resonated with your personal growth, aspirations, or a particular experience that shaped your worldview?

Think about a moment when you felt a strong sense of intellectual community or collaboration. How does Columbia's specific approach to fostering such an environment excite you and why is that important for your learning journey?
Considering Columbia's rich history and diverse student body, what contribution or perspective do you envision bringing to its campus culture that goes beyond your academic pursuits?

When you imagine yourself as a student at Columbia, what's a tangible experience or a particular scene – perhaps in a classroom, a study group, or exploring the city – that vividly illustrates why this is the right place for you to thrive?

essay_prompts.prompt: What attracts you to your intended field of study?
brainstorming_questions: Thinking about Columbia's specific approach to [Intended Field of Study], what problem or unanswered question in this field truly ignites your curiosity and makes you want to dive deeper, perhaps even more than you imagined?

Beyond the curriculum, what specific aspect of New York City, or even Columbia's unique urban environment, makes you feel that it's the absolute best place to explore your passion for [Intended Field of Study]?

When you first realized you were drawn to [Intended Field of Study], what was a moment of genuine 'aha!' or unexpected connection that solidified this interest for you, perhaps something that shifted your perspective?

Imagine you've had a conversation with a leading figure in [Intended Field of Study] at Columbia. What questions would you be most eager to ask them, and what does that tell you about what you hope to gain from your studies there?

Consider a time you faced a challenge or encountered something that seemed insurmountable, but you approached it with a unique way of thinking or problem-solving. How does that experience directly relate to the skills or mindset you believe are essential for success in [Intended Field of Study] at Columbia?

essay_prompts.prompt: In Columbia's admissions process, we use a holistic review, which means that we look at every part of your application. We encourage you to share additional details about yourself that you have not had an opportunity to share.
brainstorming_questions: Think about a time you had to explain something complex – whether it was a scientific concept, a personal belief, or a challenging situation – to someone who didn't initially understand. How did you approach bridging that gap in understanding, and what did you learn about your own perspective or communication style in the process?

Columbia emphasizes 'holistic review.' When have you felt like your true self, or a significant aspect of your identity, was overlooked or not fully appreciated in a previous context (like a standardized test score, a brief description in another application, or a conversation)? What specific details or experiences would you have shared to paint a more complete picture?

Beyond your academic achievements and extracurriculars already listed, what's a 'piece' of your personal puzzle that might surprise an admissions officer but is fundamental to who you are? Think about a passion, a habit, or a quirky interest that shapes your daily life and how you engage with the world.

Imagine you're a tour guide for Columbia, but instead of showing buildings, you're showcasing the essence of your own unique qualities and experiences. What specific 'stops' on your personal tour would you highlight, and what stories would you tell at each one to give someone a deep understanding of your journey and your potential contributions to the Columbia community?

The prompt encourages sharing details not previously shared. Is there a moment where your initial expectations or assumptions about a situation, a person, or even yourself, were completely upended? How did that moment fundamentally shift your understanding and what did it reveal about your capacity for growth and adaptation?

major_selection_tactics: Apply to a less competitive major if not set on a highly impacted field like Computer Science or Engineering, as these majors often have specific GPA and prerequisite requirements for qualification or switching.
Consider applying as '        undeclared'        for colleges like Letters and Science, as some universities do not consider an applicant'        s choice of major for admission in these colleges.
Research the competitiveness and specific admit rates for desired majors before applying, noting that '        selective'        or '        capped'        majors are highly competitive.
Review a university'        s course catalog to identify classes that genuinely interest you and align with your preferences, rather than solely focusing on major names or perceived career paths.
Take introductory classes in potential major fields before officially declaring to ensure genuine interest and aptitude.
college_ranking_tactics: Rank colleges not only based on overall prestige but also by the specific General Education (GE) requirements of each college within the university, as these can vary significantly and impact your academic experience.
Consider the quality and location of housing options when ranking colleges, as these factors can greatly influence daily life and satisfaction.
Understand that GE requirements can differ substantially between colleges, making it easier for some majors to fulfill requirements in certain colleges than others.
application_strategy.alternate_major_strategy: If applying to a highly competitive major, list a backup in a different college or a less selective field. For example, if applying to Computer Science in an Engineering school, list a major like Cognitive Science or Undeclared in the College of Letters and Science as an alternate, as some universities will review alternate majors if the primary choice is not accommodated.

scholarships.name: Columbia University Grant
scholarships.amount: Varies; meets 100% of demonstrated financial need. Potentially tuition-free for families with incomes under $150,000, with $0 parent contribution for families under $66,000. Average grant for undergraduates is approximately $76,265.
scholarships.deadline: FAFSA and CSS Profile deadlines (typically early February for regular decision for US citizens and eligible noncitizens; ISFAA for international students)
scholarships.benefits: Covers tuition, living expenses, and other costs based on demonstrated need; no loans included in aid package.
scholarships.application_method: FAFSA and CSS Profile (or ISFAA for international students)

scholarships.name: Start-Up Grants
scholarships.deadline: Automatic consideration with financial aid application
scholarships.benefits: Eases transition to college for first-year students from low-income families.
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration with financial aid application

scholarships.name: Graduate Assistantships (Teaching/Research)
scholarships.amount: Full tuition remission; stipend (e.g., $45,000 for 12 months, $40,000 for 9 months for PhD students); health and dental coverage.
scholarships.deadline: Varies by department and program (typically between January and February for Fall intake)
scholarships.benefits: Tuition remission, living stipend, professional experience, health and dental coverage.
scholarships.application_method: Application to graduate program; often indicated in the application or by the department

scholarships.name: Department of Statistics MA2PhD Merit Scholarship
scholarships.amount: Not explicitly stated, provides financial and intellectual resources
scholarships.deadline: By nomination only; award notifications on a rolling basis. Applications are for Fall 2025 admissions.
scholarships.benefits: Additional mentorship, research opportunities, doctoral-level courses, participation in MA2PhD Club activities.
scholarships.application_method: Nomination by the MA Statistics admissions committee

scholarships.name: Department of Statistics MA in Statistics Opportunity (OPP) Scholarship
scholarships.benefits: Priority placement in teaching assistant-type positions.
scholarships.application_method: Submit 2025-26 Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA). Eligible for U.S. citizens or permanent residents from underrepresented groups.

scholarships.name: Named Undergraduate Scholar Programs (e.g., John W. Kluge Scholars, John Jay Scholars)
scholarships.amount: Part of the Columbia University Grant (no additional funding beyond calculated need-based aid)
scholarships.deadline: Automatic selection from first-year applicants during the admissions process
scholarships.benefits: Recognition of accomplishments, attached to the Columbia University Grant.
scholarships.application_method: Automatic selection by the admissions committee from first-year applicants

scholarships.name: Columbia University Graduate Merit Scholarships
scholarships.deadline: Varies by program/department; often automatic consideration with admission.
scholarships.application_method: Awarded to top-performing students in master's and Ph.D. programs; likely automatic consideration based on admission application, but may vary by department.

ap_policy.general_rule: Satisfactory scores on AP Exams may grant credit or exemption; a maximum of 16 points of credit can be earned through AP and IB exams combined. Score requirements vary by discipline, with some humanities requiring a 5, and calculus/physics potentially accepting a 4 or 5.
exceptions: AP credit does not fulfill general education (Core Curriculum) requirements for incoming first-years.
Credit and placement decisions are department-specific; some departments (e.g., Philosophy) do not accept AP credit.
Specific math course prerequisites apply; no AP credit if MATH UN1101 is taken.
For economics, a score of 5 on one test and at least a 4 on the other is required for both microeconomics and macroeconomics.
AP exams without a lab component may not fulfill lab requirements for science majors.
ap_policy.usage: Can satisfy prerequisites, grant advanced placement, or reduce the total credits needed for graduation. Can also free up a semester or two for double majors, research, or study abroad, but will not automatically remove every required Core course.

ib_policy.general_rule: Higher Level (HL) exams with scores of 6 or 7 grant credit, if the academic discipline is represented at Columbia College. A maximum of 16 points of credit can be earned through IB and AP exams combined.

transfer_articulation.restrictions: Maximum of 60 transfer credits for BA candidates in the School of General Studies, or 64 points in Columbia College and 68 points in Columbia Engineering (these caps include AP/IB credits). Courses must be from an accredited institution, academic, consistent with Columbia'        s undergraduate courses, and carry a grade of '        C'        or higher ('        C-'        or better for Columbia College, '        B'        or better for Columbia Engineering). No credit for courses taken after matriculation at GS (with exceptions). All instruction must be face-to-face; no online courses accepted. Transfer credit must be finalized within six months of matriculation for GS students. Columbia does not grant credit for college courses taken before a student'        s graduation from high school, with the exception of standardized exams (AP, IB), which are limited to 16 points.

what_it_takes: Strong academic record with challenging coursework, ideally in the top 10% of your high school class, with a GPA near 4.0 in rigorous courses (AP, IB, honors).
High standardized test scores (SAT 1490-1570 or ACT 34-35), though Columbia is test-optional, strong scores can enhance an application.
Demonstrated intellectual curiosity, resilience, and a love for learning through academic projects, research, or independent studies.
Evidence of leadership potential and meaningful impact in extracurricular pursuits, focusing on quality over quantity.
Authentic essays that reveal personality, values, motivations, and a clear understanding of how you would fit into and contribute to the Columbia community.
common_activities: Research experience, sometimes with abstract submissions.
Leadership roles in school clubs and organizations (e.g., Student Council, Model UN, Quiz Bowl).
Community service and volunteer work, demonstrating positive impact.
Involvement in arts (e.g., photography, orchestra, painting/drawing).
essay_tips: Be specific about why Columbia University, mentioning particular programs, courses, professors, clubs, or the Core Curriculum.
Show, don't tell: use specific moments or anecdotes from personal or professional experiences to illustrate your passions and goals, rather than just stating them.
Avoid generic essays that could apply to any school; tailor each essay specifically to Columbia.
Proofread carefully for grammar, spelling, and typos, and ensure you mention Columbia correctly.
Reflect on a source of happiness and express your unique perspective or lived experience, demonstrating how it would enrich Columbia'        s diverse community.
red_flags: Generic essays that do not show specific interest in Columbia.
Failure to follow application instructions, including word limits and submission guidelines.
Repeating information from your resume without adding new insights in your essays.
Not submitting on time, especially for early decision or video interviews.

insights.insight: Columbia employs a holistic admissions review, considering all parts of the application and the applicant as a whole person, in context of their unique circumstances.
The university seeks students with deep curiosity and dynamism who will critically and enthusiastically engage with diverse people and ideas.
Demonstrating how you will benefit from and contribute to the Columbia community is crucial.
Commitment to a few meaningful extracurricular activities is preferred over superficial involvement in many.
Early Decision can be a strategic option if Columbia is your definite first choice, as it is a binding contract.
